# Tornado records

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Super_Outbreak_Map.jpg/250px-
Super_Outbreak_Map.jpg)](/wiki/File:Super_Outbreak_Map.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Super_Outbreak_Map.jpg "Enlarge")

A map of the tornado paths in the [1974 Super
Outbreak](/wiki/1974_Super_Outbreak "1974 Super Outbreak")

This article lists various **[tornado](/wiki/Tornado "Tornado")
[records](/wiki/List_of_weather_records "List of weather records")**. The most
"extreme" tornado in [recorded history](/wiki/Recorded_history "Recorded
history") was the [Tri-State Tornado](/wiki/Tri-State_Tornado "Tri-State
Tornado"), which spread through parts of [Missouri](/wiki/Missouri
"Missouri"), [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois"), and
[Indiana](/wiki/Indiana "Indiana") on March 18, 1925. It is considered an F5,
though tornadoes were not ranked on any scale in that era. It holds records
for longest path length at 219 miles (352 km), longest duration at about 3½
hours, and fastest forward speed for a significant tornado at 73 mph (117
km/h) anywhere on Earth. In addition, it is the deadliest single tornado in
United States history with 695 fatalities.[1] It was also the third-costliest
tornado in history at the time, but has been surpassed by several others non-
normalized. When costs are normalized for wealth and inflation, it still ranks
third today.[2]

The deadliest tornado in world history was the [Daulatpur–Saturia
tornado](/wiki/Daulatpur%E2%80%93Saturia_tornado "Daulatpur–Saturia tornado")
in [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") on April 26, 1989, which killed
approximately 1,300 people.[3] In its history Bangladesh has had at least 19
tornadoes kill more than 100 people, almost half of the [total for the rest of
the world](/wiki/List_of_tornadoes_causing_100_or_more_deaths "List of
tornadoes causing 100 or more deaths").

For 37 years, the most extensive [tornado outbreak](/wiki/Tornado_outbreak
"Tornado outbreak") on record, in almost every category, was the [1974 Super
Outbreak](/wiki/1974_Super_Outbreak "1974 Super Outbreak"), which affected a
large area of the central United States and extreme southern
[Ontario](/wiki/Ontario "Ontario") in Canada on April 3 and April 4, 1974. Not
only did this outbreak feature 148 tornadoes in only 18 hours, but an
unprecedented number of them were violent; 7 were of F5 intensity and 23 were
F4. During the peak of this outbreak there were 16 tornadoes on the ground at
the same time. More than 300 people, possibly as many as 330, were killed by
tornadoes during this outbreak. However, this record was later broken during
the [2011 Super Outbreak](/wiki/2011_Super_Outbreak "2011 Super Outbreak"),
which resulted in 362 tornadoes and 324 tornadic fatalities.[4]

## Tornado
outbreaks[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Tornado outbreaks")]

### Most tornadoes in single 24-hour
period[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Most tornadoes in single 24-hour period")]

The [2011 Super Outbreak](/wiki/2011_Super_Outbreak "2011 Super Outbreak") was
the most prolific tornado outbreak in USA history. It produced 362 tornadoes,
with 218 of those in a single 24-hour period on April 27,[5] including 11 EF4
and 4 EF5 tornadoes. 348 deaths occurred in that outbreak, of which 324 were
tornado related. The outbreak helped smash the record for most tornadoes in
the month of April with 772 tornadoes, almost triple the prior record (267 in
April 1974). The overall record for a single month was 542 in May 2003, which
was also broken.[6]

The infamous [1974 Super Outbreak](/wiki/1974_Super_Outbreak "1974 Super
Outbreak") of April 3–4, 1974, which spawned 148 confirmed tornadoes across
eastern North America, held the record for the most prolific tornado outbreak
for many years. Not only did it produce an exceptional number of tornadoes,
but it was also an inordinately intense outbreak producing dozens of large,
long-track tornadoes, including 7 F5 and 23 F4 tornadoes. More significant
tornadoes occurred within 24 hours than any other week in the tornado
record.[7] Due to a secular trend in tornado reporting, the 2011 and 1974
tornado counts are not directly comparable.

### Longest continuous outbreak and largest autumnal
outbreak[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Longest continuous outbreak and largest autumnal outbreak")]

Most tornado outbreaks in North America occur in the spring, but there is a
secondary peak of tornado activity in the fall which is less consistent but
can include exceptionally large and/or intense outbreaks. In 1992, an
estimated [95 tornadoes](/wiki/November_1992_tornado_outbreak "November 1992
tornado outbreak") broke out in a record 41 hours of continuous [tornado
activity](/wiki/November_1992_tornado_outbreak "November 1992 tornado
outbreak") from November 21 to 23. This is also among the largest-known
outbreaks in areal expanse. Many other very large outbreaks have occurred in
autumn, especially in October and November.[1]

### Greatest number of tornadoes spawned from a
hurricane[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Greatest number of tornadoes spawned from a hurricane")]

The greatest number of tornadoes spawned from a hurricane is 118 from
[Hurricane Ivan](/wiki/Hurricane_Ivan_tornado_outbreak "Hurricane Ivan tornado
outbreak") in 2004.[8] Caution is advised comparing the raw number of counted
tornadoes from recent decades to decades prior to the 1990s since more
tornadoes that occur are now recorded than in the past.

### Deadliest single tornado in world
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Deadliest single tornado in world history")]

On April 26, 1989 in [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") a [massive
tornado](/wiki/Daulatpur%E2%80%93Saturia_tornado "Daulatpur–Saturia tornado")
took at least 1,300 lives.[9]

### Deadliest single tornado in US
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Deadliest single tornado in US history")]

The [Tri-State Tornado](/wiki/Tri-State_Tornado "Tri-State Tornado") of March
18, 1925 killed 695 people in [Missouri](/wiki/Missouri "Missouri") (11),
[Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois") (613), and [Indiana](/wiki/Indiana
"Indiana") (71). The outbreak it occurred with was also the deadliest known
[tornado outbreak](/wiki/Tornado_outbreak "Tornado outbreak"), with a combined
death toll of 747 across the Mississippi River Valley.[1][10][11]

### Most damaging
tornado[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Most damaging tornado")]

Similar to fatalities, damage (and observations) of a tornado are a
coincidence of what character of tornado interacts with certain
characteristics of built up areas. That is, destructive tornadoes are in a
sense "accidents" of a large tornado striking a large population. In addition
to population and changes thereof, comparing damage historically is subject to
changes in wealth and inflation. The [1896 St. Louis–East St. Louis
tornado](/wiki/1896_St._Louis%E2%80%93East_St._Louis_tornado "1896 St.
Louis–East St. Louis tornado") on May 27, incurred the most damages adjusted
for wealth and inflation, at an estimated $2.9 billion (1997 USD). In raw
numbers, the [Joplin tornado](/wiki/2011_Joplin_tornado "2011 Joplin tornado")
of May 22, 2011 is considered the costliest tornado in recent history, with
damage totals near $2.8 billion (2011 USD). Until 2011, the "[Bridge Creek-
Moore tornado](/wiki/1999_Bridge_Creek-Moore_tornado "1999 Bridge Creek-Moore
tornado")" of May 3, 1999 was the most damaging.[12]

## Largest and most powerful
tornadoes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Largest and most powerful tornadoes")]

### Highest winds observed in a
tornado[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Highest winds observed in a tornado")]

During the F5 [1999 Bridge Creek–Moore
tornado](/wiki/1999_Bridge_Creek%E2%80%93Moore_tornado "1999 Bridge
Creek–Moore tornado") on May 3, 1999 in the southern [Oklahoma City
metro](/wiki/Oklahoma_City_Metropolitan_Area "Oklahoma City Metropolitan
Area") area, a [Doppler on Wheels](/wiki/Doppler_on_Wheels "Doppler on
Wheels") situated near the tornado measured winds of 302 ± 20 mph (486 ± 32
km/h) momentarily in a small area inside the funnel approximately 100 m (330
ft) above ground level.[13] These are also the highest wind speeds observed on
Earth.

On May 31, 2013, a tornado hit rural areas near [El Reno,
Oklahoma](/wiki/El_Reno,_Oklahoma "El Reno, Oklahoma"). The tornado was
originally rated as an EF3 based on damage; however, after mobile radar data
analysis was conducted, it was concluded to have been an EF5 due to a measured
wind speed of greater than 296 mph (476 km/h), second only to the Bridge Creek
- Moore tornado. Revised RaXPol analysis found winds of 302 mph (486 km/h)
well above ground level and ≥291 mph (468 km/h) below 10 m (33 ft) with some
subvortices moving at 175 mph (282 km/h).[14] These winds may possibly be as
high or higher than the winds recorded on May 3, 1999. Despite the recorded
windspeed, the El Reno tornado was later downgraded back to EF3 due to the
fact that no EF5 damage was found, likely due to the lack of sufficient damage
indicators in the largely rural area west of [Oklahoma
City](/wiki/Oklahoma_City "Oklahoma City").[15][16]

Winds were measured at 257–268 mph (414–431 km/h) using portable Doppler radar
in the [Red Rock, Oklahoma](/wiki/Red_Rock,_Oklahoma "Red Rock, Oklahoma")
tornado during the [April 26, 1991 tornado
outbreak](/wiki/April_26,_1991_tornado_outbreak "April 26, 1991 tornado
outbreak") in north-central Oklahoma. Though these winds are possibly
indicative of an F5 strength tornado, this particular tornado's path never
encountered any significant structures and caused minimal damage. Thus it was
rated an F4.[17]

### Longest damage path and
duration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Longest damage path and duration")]

The longest-known track for a single tornado is the [Tri-State
Tornado](/wiki/Tri-State_Tornado "Tri-State Tornado") with a path length of
151 to 235 mi (243 to 378 km). For years there was debate whether the
originally recognized path length of 219 mi (352 km) over 3.5 hours was from
one tornado or a series. Some very long track (VLT) tornadoes were later
determined to be successive tornadoes spawned by the same supercell
thunderstorm, which are known as a [tornado family](/wiki/Tornado_family
"Tornado family"). The Tri-State Tornado, however, appeared to have no gaps in
the damage. A six-year reanalysis study by a team of severe convective storm
meteorologists found insufficient evidence to make firm conclusions but does
conclude that it is likely that the beginning and ending of the path was
resultant of separate tornadoes comprising a tornado family. It also found
that the tornado began 15 mi (24 km) to the west and ended 1 mi (1.6 km)
farther east than previously known, bringing the total path to 235 mi (378
km). The 174 mi (280 km) segment from central [Madison County,
Missouri](/wiki/Madison_County,_Missouri "Madison County, Missouri") to [Pike
County, Indiana](/wiki/Pike_County,_Indiana "Pike County, Indiana") is likely
one continuous tornado and the 151 mi (243 km) segment from central [Bollinger
County, Missouri](/wiki/Bollinger_County,_Missouri "Bollinger County,
Missouri") to western Pike County, Indiana is very likely a single continuous
tornado. Another [significant](/wiki/Glossary_of_tornado_terms#S "Glossary of
tornado terms") tornado was found about 65 mi (105 km) east-northeast of the
end of aforementioned segment(s) of the Tri-State Tornado Family and is likely
another member of the family. Its path length of 20 mi (32 km) over about 20
minutes makes the known tornado family path length total to 320 mi (510 km)
over about 5½ hours.[18] [Grazulis](/wiki/Thomas_P._Grazulis "Thomas P.
Grazulis") in 2001 wrote that the first 60 mi (97 km) of the (originally
recognized) track is probably the result of two or more tornadoes and that a
path length of 157 mi (253 km) was seemingly continuous.[19]

### Longest path and duration tornado
family[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Longest path and duration tornado family")]

What at one time was thought to be the record holder for the longest tornado
path is now thought to be the longest tornado family, with a track of at least
293 miles (472 km) on May 26, 1917 from the Missouri border across Illinois
into Indiana. It caused severe damage and mass casualties in
[Charleston](/wiki/Charleston,_Illinois "Charleston, Illinois") and [Mattoon,
Illinois](/wiki/Mattoon,_Illinois "Mattoon, Illinois").[1]

What was probably the longest track [supercell](/wiki/Supercell "Supercell")
thunderstorm tracked 790 miles (1,270 km) across 6 states in 17.5 hours on
March 12, 2006 as part of the [March 2006 tornado outbreak
sequence](/wiki/March_2006_tornado_outbreak_sequence "March 2006 tornado
outbreak sequence"). It began in [Noble County,
Oklahoma](/wiki/Noble_County,_Oklahoma "Noble County, Oklahoma") and ended in
[Jackson County, Michigan](/wiki/Jackson_County,_Michigan "Jackson County,
Michigan"), producing many tornadoes in Missouri and Illinois.[20]

### Largest path
width[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Largest path width")]

Officially, the widest tornado on record is the [El Reno,
Oklahoma](/wiki/El_Reno,_Oklahoma "El Reno, Oklahoma")
[tornado](/wiki/2013_El_Reno_tornado "2013 El Reno tornado") of May 31, 2013
with a width of 2.6 miles (4.2 km) at its peak. This is the width found by the
National Weather Service based on preliminary data from University of Oklahoma
RaxPol mobile radar that also sampled winds of 296 mph (476 km/h) which was
used to upgrade the tornado to EF5.[21] However, it was revealed that these
winds did not impact any structures, and as a result the tornado was
downgraded to EF3 based on damage.[22] However, another possible contender for
the widest tornado as measured by radar was the F4
[Mulhall](/wiki/Mulhall,_Oklahoma "Mulhall, Oklahoma") tornado in north-
central Oklahoma which occurred during the [1999 Oklahoma tornado
outbreak](/wiki/1999_Oklahoma_tornado_outbreak "1999 Oklahoma tornado
outbreak"). The [diameter of the maximum winds](/wiki/Radius_of_maximum_wind
"Radius of maximum wind") (over 110 mph (49 m/s)) was over 5,200 feet (1,600
m) as measured by a DOW radar. Although the tornado passed largely over rural
terrain, the width of the wind swath capable of producing damage was as wide
as 4 mi (6.4 km).[23][24]

The F4 [Hallam, Nebraska](/wiki/Hallam,_Nebraska "Hallam, Nebraska")
[tornado](/wiki/2004_Hallam,_Nebraska_tornado "2004 Hallam, Nebraska tornado")
during the [outbreak](/wiki/May_2004_tornado_outbreak_sequence "May 2004
tornado outbreak sequence") of May 22, 2004 was the previous official record
holder for the widest tornado, surveyed at 2.5 miles (4.0 km) wide. A similar
size tornado struck [Edmonson, Texas](/wiki/Edmonson,_Texas "Edmonson, Texas")
on May 31, 1968, when a damage path width between 2 to 3 miles (3.2 to 4.8 km)
was recorded from an F3 tornado.[25]

### Highest forward
speed[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Highest forward speed")]

Seventy-three miles per hour (117 km/h) from the Tri-State Tornado (other weak
tornadoes have approached or exceeded this speed, but this is the fastest
forward movement observed in a major tornado).[1]

### Greatest pressure
drop[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Greatest pressure drop")]

A [pressure](/wiki/Atmospheric_pressure "Atmospheric pressure") deficit of 100
millibars (2.95 inHg) was observed when a violent
[tornado](/wiki/2003_South_Dakota_tornado_outbreak "2003 South Dakota tornado
outbreak") near [Manchester, South Dakota](/wiki/Manchester,_South_Dakota
"Manchester, South Dakota") on June 24, 2003 passed directly over an [in-
situ](/wiki/In-situ "In-situ") probe that storm chasing researcher [Tim
Samaras](/wiki/Tim_Samaras "Tim Samaras") deployed.[26] In less than a minute,
the pressure dropped to 850 millibars (25.10 inHg), which are the greatest
pressure decline and the lowest pressure ever recorded at the Earth's surface
when adjusted to sea level.[27][28]

On April 21, 2007, a 194-millibar (5.73 inHg) pressure deficit was reported
when a [tornado](/wiki/List_of_late-
April_2007_tornado_outbreak_sequence_tornadoes "List of late-April 2007
tornado outbreak sequence tornadoes") struck a [storm
chasing](/wiki/Storm_chasing "Storm chasing") vehicle in [Tulia,
Texas](/wiki/Tulia,_Texas "Tulia, Texas").[29] The tornado caused EF2 damage
as it passed through Tulia. The reported pressure drop far exceeds that which
would be expected based on theoretical calculations.[30]

There is a questionable and unofficial citizen's barometer measurement of a
192-millibar (5.67 inHg) drop around [Minneapolis](/wiki/Minneapolis
"Minneapolis") in 1904.[31]

## Early
tornadoes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Early tornadoes")]

### Earliest-known tornado in
Europe[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Earliest-known tornado in Europe")]

  * The earliest recorded tornado in Europe struck Rosdalla, near [Kilbeggan](/wiki/Kilbeggan "Kilbeggan"), Ireland on April 30, 1054. The earliest-known British tornado hit central London on October 23, 1091 and was [especially destructive](/wiki/London_tornado_of_1091 "London tornado of 1091").[32]

### Earliest-known tornado in the
Americas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Earliest-known tornado in the Americas")]

  * An apparent tornado is recorded to have struck [Tlatelolco](/wiki/Tlatelolco_\(altepetl\) "Tlatelolco \(altepetl\)") (present day [Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City")), on August 21, 1521, two days before the Aztec capital's fall to [Cortés](/wiki/Hern%C3%A1n_Cort%C3%A9s "Hernán Cortés"). Many other tornadoes are documented historically within the [Basin of Mexico](/wiki/Basin_of_Mexico "Basin of Mexico").[33]

### First confirmed tornado and first tornado fatality in present-day United
States[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: First confirmed tornado and first tornado fatality in present-day
United States")]

  * August 1671 - [Rehoboth, Massachusetts](/wiki/Rehoboth,_Massachusetts "Rehoboth, Massachusetts")[34][35]
  * July 8, 1680 - [Cambridge, Massachusetts](/wiki/Cambridge,_Massachusetts "Cambridge, Massachusetts") \- 1 dead[1][36]

## Exceptional tornado
droughts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Exceptional tornado droughts")]

### Longest span without a tornado rated F5 or
EF5[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Longest span without a tornado rated F5 or EF5")]

Before the [Greensburg EF5 tornado](/wiki/May_2007_tornado_outbreak "May 2007
tornado outbreak") on May 4, 2007, it had been 8 years and one day since the
US had a **confirmed** F5 or EF5 tornado. The last confirmed F5 or EF5 had hit
southern [Oklahoma City metro](/wiki/Oklahoma_City_metropolitan_area "Oklahoma
City metropolitan area") area and surrounding communities during the [May 3,
1999 event](/wiki/1999_Oklahoma_tornado_outbreak "1999 Oklahoma tornado
outbreak"). This is the longest interval without an F5 or EF5 tornado since
official records began in 1950.

## Exceptional
survivors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Exceptional survivors")]

### Longest distance carried by a
tornado[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=23 "Edit
section: Longest distance carried by a tornado")]

Matt Suter of [Fordland, Missouri](/wiki/Fordland,_Missouri "Fordland,
Missouri") holds the record for the longest-known distance traveled by anyone
picked up by a tornado who lived to tell about it. On March 12, 2006 he was
carried 1,307 feet (398 m), 13 feet (4.0 m) shy of one-quarter mile (400 m),
according to National Weather Service measurements.[37][38]

### Codell,
Kansas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Codell, Kansas")]

The small town of [Codell, Kansas](/wiki/Codell,_Kansas "Codell, Kansas"), was
hit by a tornado on the same date (May 20) three consecutive years: 1916,
1917, and 1918.[39][40] The U.S. has about 100,000 thunderstorms a year; less
than one percent produce a tornado. The odds of this coincidence occurring
again is extremely small.

### Tanner/Harvest,
Alabama[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Tanner/Harvest, Alabama")]

[Tanner](/wiki/Tanner,_Alabama "Tanner, Alabama"), a small town in northern
Alabama, was hit by an F5 tornado on [April 3, 1974](/wiki/1974_Super_Outbreak
"1974 Super Outbreak") and was struck again 45 minutes later by a second F5
(however, the rating is disputed and it may have been high-end F4),
demolishing what remained of the town. Thirty-seven years later, on [April 27,
2011](/wiki/April_25%E2%80%9328,_2011_tornado_outbreak "April 25–28, 2011
tornado outbreak") (the largest and deadliest outbreak since 1974), Tanner was
hit yet again by the EF5 [2011 Hackleburg–Phil Campbell, Alabama
tornado](/wiki/2011_Hackleburg%E2%80%93Phil_Campbell,_Alabama_tornado "2011
Hackleburg–Phil Campbell, Alabama tornado"), which produced high-end EF4
damage in the southern portion of town. The suburban community of [Harvest,
Alabama](/wiki/Harvest,_Alabama "Harvest, Alabama"), just to the northeast,
also sustained major impacts from all three Tanner tornadoes, and was also hit
by destructive tornadoes in [1995](/wiki/1995_Anderson_Hills_tornado "1995
Anderson Hills tornado") and
[2012](/wiki/March_2%E2%80%933,_2012_tornado_outbreak "March 2–3, 2012 tornado
outbreak").

### Moore,
Oklahoma[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Moore, Oklahoma")]

The south [Oklahoma City](/wiki/Oklahoma_City "Oklahoma City") suburb of
[Moore, Oklahoma](/wiki/Moore,_Oklahoma "Moore, Oklahoma") was hit by
tornadoes in 1973, [1999](/wiki/1999_Bridge_Creek_%E2%80%93_Moore_tornado
"1999 Bridge Creek – Moore tornado"),
[2003](/wiki/May_2003_tornado_outbreak_sequence#Moore_Tornado_\(F4\) "May 2003
tornado outbreak sequence"), [2010](/wiki/Early-
May_2010_tornado_outbreak#Moore_–_Choctaw_tornado "Early-May 2010 tornado
outbreak"), [2013](/wiki/2013_Moore_tornado "2013 Moore tornado"), and 2015,
five of which were of F4/EF4 strength or greater, although it was determined
that the tornado in 2003 caused no F4 damage within Moore itself, but in areas
to its northeast. The 1999 and 2013 events were rated F5 and EF5,
respectively. In total, about 23 tornadoes have struck within the immediate
vicinity of Moore since 1890, the most recent of which was an EF2 on March 25,
2015.[41]

### Jackson,
Tennessee[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Jackson, Tennessee")]

The city of [Jackson, Tennessee](/wiki/Jackson,_Tennessee "Jackson,
Tennessee") has been hit by an F4/EF4 tornado three separate times, in
[1999](/wiki/January_17%E2%80%9318,_1999_tornado_outbreak "January 17–18, 1999
tornado outbreak"), [2003](/wiki/May_2003_tornado_outbreak_sequence "May 2003
tornado outbreak sequence"), and
[2008](/wiki/2008_Super_Tuesday_tornado_outbreak "2008 Super Tuesday tornado
outbreak"). Interestingly, all three of these tornadoes occurred after dark
and were preceded or followed by a separate F3/EF3 tornado that caused
additional destruction in the Jackson area.

### Grand Island,
Nebraska[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tornado_records&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Grand Island, Nebraska")]

[Grand Island, Nebraska](/wiki/Grand_Island,_Nebraska "Grand Island,
Nebraska") [was hit by seven tornadoes in 4
hours.](/wiki/1980_Grand_Island_tornado_outbreak "1980 Grand Island tornado
outbreak")
